moves.2. e3: Not sure if this has a name.
moves.2... c5: Black turns the tables and doe a little reverse Queens Gambit action.
moves.3... cxd4: Never a bad idea for a C pawn to take a D pawn.
moves.4. exd4: Now black has E and D pawns in place but white has lost the E pawn.  Could be bad for white.
moves.7. h3: White says do it or get off the pot.
moves.7... Bxf3: Black takes the protector which leaves the white D pawn unprotected
moves.8... Nxd4: Black takes is bounty and it now one point up.
moves.10... e6: Black ignores the threat and develops a pawn.
moves.11... bxc6: Black captures with pawn and leaves his only Pawn hole on the B column.  Moving the hole away from the center is never a bad idea.  Notice white a gaping pawn hole on E and D.  Looks bad.
moves.12... Bd6: Black develops and plays a little chase the queen.  This slows down the white development because he has to retreet.
moves.13. Qd4: Queen finds a safe square to hang out on.
moves.15... d4: Black is feeling very bold.  This is a classic forking maneuver.  Both B and N are in trouble.
moves.16. Bxd4: White saves a little face but not much.
moves.17. Ne2: Strange that white did not take pawn with Q.  Instead the horse high tails it away.
moves.18. c3: White does not like that black pawn there.
moves.19. bxc3: White captures back.  White now has an isolated P on the C column.  Not good.
moves.19... Bc5: Black uncovers the Queen so now Q threatens Q.
moves.21. Ng3: I guess white horse is worried and wants to stop up a hole in the dike.
moves.21... g6: Black pushes pawn to thwart advancment from black horse.
moves.22... Rab8: Black brings rook to control more territory.
moves.23. Rae1: white threatens pawn although it is protected.
moves.25. Qxe4: Black is now glad that he added the extra protection to e pawn.
moves.26... Re7: making plans to double the rooks if needed.
moves.27... f5: Let us play chase the rook.
moves.28. Rh4: setting up to possibly hurt the king.
moves.28... h5: Black takes measures to protect king.
moves.29. Qc1: White queen is looking for a hole to get behind enemy lines.
moves.30. Qg5: White queen is looking for openings
moves.31. Rd1: white rook wants to join the pressure.
moves.31... Rb7: Black is protecting the kings roow.
moves.32... Qc7: Black queen protects pawn and also bishop.
moves.33. Kf1: White king does not want to get stuck back there.
moves.33... e4: Always a good idea to make a chain.  Also, black opens a hole for black queen to get behind enemy lines.
moves.34... Be7: Black finds a brilliant move. Looks very bad for white.
moves.35... Qxc4+: Rather than taking immediate bounty, white delays gratification and puts white in check.
moves.36... Qxd5: Black finds another nuget of gold and on top of everything that white rook is still in a world of hurt.
moves.37... Qd1+: Black counters the threat with a check.
moves.38... Bd6: Once again, black could have taken a rook but he decides instead to pin the queen.. White must be sweatilng.
moves.39. e5: White comes up with a good block to save the queen.
moves.39... Be7: Black goes back again to threaten his second choice.
moves.40. e6: White is running out of ideas.  He pushes a pawn for unknown reasons.
moves.40... Bd6: AGAIN, black pins the queen.   There is no way out this time.
moves.41. Qxd6: White has to cut his loses.
moves.41... Qxd6+: White is now 14 points down and also in check.
